qas.question: What nationality began birthing groups who expanded the vocabulary of punk music?
From what region did the group Devo originate?
Where was the band Talking Heads based out of?
Who did the Talking Heads begin a series of collaborations with in 1978?
What region's post-punk scene incorporated ideas from Theater of Cruelty?
When did the American groups begin to really get in on the post-punk movement?
Which American bands had ties to the Manchester punk scene?
What were some Midwestern punk bands?
What did Pere and Devo draw inspiration for their music from?
What were groups in San Francisco's post-punk scene?
What groups were not interested in the punk scene?
Which environments were not inspirational to music?
What elements were never combined with punk?
What year was the least influential for post-punk?

context: In the <a5_0>mid 1970s<a5_0/>, various <a0_0><b10_0>American<b10_0/><a0_0/> groups (some with ties to Downtown Manhattan's punk scene, including <a6_0>Television and Suicide<a6_0/>) had begun expanding on the vocabulary of punk music. <a1_0>Midwestern<a1_0/> groups such as <a7_0>Pere Ubu and Devo<a7_0/> drew inspiration from the region's <a8_0><b11_0>derelict industrial environments<b11_0/><a8_0/>, employing conceptual art techniques, musique concrète and unconventional verbal styles that would presage the post-punk movement by several years. A variety of subsequent groups, including <a2_0>New York<a2_0/>-based Talking Heads and Boston-based Mission of Burma, combined elements of punk with <b12_0>art school sensibilities<b12_0/>. In <b13_0>1978<b13_0/>, the former band began a series of collaborations with British ambient pioneer and ex-Roxy Music member <a3_0>Brian Eno<a3_0/>, experimenting with Dada-influenced lyrical techniques, dance music, and African polyrhythms. <a4_0>San Francisco's<a4_0/> vibrant post-punk scene was centered around such groups as <a9_0>Chrome, the Residents and Tuxedomoon<a9_0/>, who incorporated multimedia experimentation, film and ideas from Antonin Artaud's Theater of Cruelty.
